channel.title: Where are good Java tutorials?
channel.description:
I'm really trying to advance in java. I want to be good at it. Though, I don't like lots of technical reading (As you'd see on Oracles website). I want some real tutorials that don't just [b]feed you the code[/b]. Every tutorial I've found says [b]Copy and Paste this code and run it[/b]. That's not a tutorial, that's spoonfeeding. No, I don't want to learn Java through RSPS programming (as I've been doing as is). I want to build simple apps, and such.
Where should I go :S
Note: I can get books, I'm doing this in class at my school, and if I show dedication, my teacher will get me a book for it.

item.title: Where are good Java tutorials?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

I don’t really have a problem with that (quite the contrary; object forms of int, byte etc would be pretty usefull).
It’s just that java is already so verbose… xD

As for the OP:
The docs on Oracle’s site are HELPFULL. Sometimes when I’m stuck with an object I read up on Oracle’s site for field details, etc…
I suggest you learn Java package by package;
java.util
java.io
java.awt
java.awt.event
javax.swing (for UI development, along with java.awt)

Read full topic

item.title: Where are good Java tutorials?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:22, topic:514361”][quote author=object link=topic=632611.msg4278463#msg4278463 date=1365231926]
In an upcoming version of Java (10 or later), they might remove primitive types.
[/quote]
why would they do that?[/quote]Unless it’s because they want Java to be a 100% Object-Oriented language, I have no idea. But they told they might want to add a unified type system. You can read more here http://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/03/07/oracle_java_9_10_roadmap/ .

Read full topic

item.title: Where are good Java tutorials?
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:20, topic:514361”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=632611.msg4278278#msg4278278 date=1365208213]

[quote author=imthenull link=topic=632611.msg4278275#msg4278275 date=1365207838]

programming Java (well… That’s kind of OOP)
[/quote]You do realize java is strictly an object oriented language, right? Not ‘kind of’.

int isn’t an object. byte isn’t an object.

Yes they are. All primitive types can be implicitly converted to their respective classes (Byte, Short, Integer, Long).

I’m on my iPad right now so I can’t really write a more descriptive response right now.

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/datatypes.html
“Primitive types are special data types built into the language; they are not objects created from a class.”

You also can’t use primitive types as generic parameters.
[/quote]That why I said they can be implicitly converted to their respective types… check out the Number class[/quote]

That doesn’t make them the object that they are cast to. I can cast objects of different types, that doesn’t make them the same type. An Integer is an object, an int is a primitive type. I hope you haven’t been using Integer for calculations because instead of being a number, it is simply a pointer that references the number and therefore takes more CPU to process.

Can you do this?:

int x = 3; System.out.println(x.parseInt());

No, you must use the Integer class, because int is not an object.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69

In an upcoming version of Java (10 or later), they might remove primitive types.

why would they do that?

item.title: Where are good Java tutorials?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

In an upcoming version of Java (10 or later), they might remove primitive types. Other than that, you can cast any primitive type to Object.

Read full topic

item.title: Where are good Java tutorials?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:10, topic:514361”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=632611.msg4277259#msg4277259 date=1365094289]
I honestly am with imthenull on this one. If you can’t sit down with a book and allow the book to explain it in a more complex manner then you won’t go anywhere fast. I’m not trying to be a dick or anything, that’s just the way it goes. Books and documentation are essential to any programmer.
[/quote]Pretty much. Even if you do “learn” it some other way, to advance properly the docs are you best friend.[/quote]
If I was to still learn the correct ways of OOP, and not shit ways of programming Java (well… That’s kind of OOP), what would matter.

CoonHunter:

I can help teach and explain if you want. I finally got Skype going just shoot me a pm.

I learn better hands on lol.

Read full topic
